channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 The New York Times Company

item.title: Thousands Flee in Gaza as Israel Orders More Evacuations
item.description: The Israeli military says its campaign will soon become less intense, but Palestinians were once again racing to escape the fighting in southern Gaza, including Khan Younis.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman, Iyad Abuheweila, Bilal Shbair and Thomas Fuller
item.media:description: Palestinians fleeing from Khan Younis following an evacuation order by the Israeli army.

item.title: Middle East Crisis: Mediators Seek to Revive Stalled Gaza Cease-Fire Talks
item.description: Qatar sent Hamas potential amendments last week to a proposed deal backed by the United Nations and United States, according to two senior officials involved in the talks.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: A Family Loses 3 Generations of Women in India Crowd’s Panic
item.description: They had worked hard for years to make a life: “Now it’s over with the death of my dear daughter, wife and mother — in one single blow.”
item.dc:creator: Suhasini Raj and Saumya Khandelwal
item.media:description: Vinod Kumar, center, mourning over the bodies of his wife and daughter, who died in Tuesday’s stampede.

item.title: Kings Battle for an Ancient Throne in Nigeria
item.description: Two men claim to be the emir of Kano, an ancient kingdom in northern Nigeria. Their struggle for power and influence is feeding into a wider competition ahead of the country’s next election.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Maclean and Ismail Auwal
item.media:credit: Tom Saater for The New York Times
item.media:description: Emir Muhammad Sanusi II receiving his subjects in June. Emir Sanusi is one of two men vying for the throne in the emirate of Kano.

item.title: Jamaicans prepare for the arrival of Beryl.
item.dc:creator: Jovan Johnson
item.media:description: Storm clouds hover over the mountains in Kingston, Jamaica, as people prepare for Hurricane Beryl on Wednesday.

item.title: Hurricane Beryl Caused ‘Unimaginable’ Damage in Grenada, Leader Says
item.description: As the storm headed for Jamaica, officials were assessing what Grenada’s prime minister called “total” devastation on two of the country’s islands.
item.dc:creator: Emiliano Rodríguez Mega
item.media:description: Repairing a roof in Grenada’s capital, St. George’s, on Tuesday. Officials said Hurricane Beryl did far more damage to the islands of Carriacou and Petite Martinique, where communications were down.

item.title: Hurricane Beryl Roars Through the Caribbean: Photos and Video
item.description: A look at the destruction caused by Hurricane Beryl as it lashes its way through the Caribbean.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: Oistins, Barbados, on Monday after Hurricane Beryl passed over.

item.title: Why the Supreme Court Immunity Ruling Worries U.S. Allies
item.description: Legal experts say the U.S. Supreme Court ruling pushes past most of the norms in effect among American allies, adding more concern about the reliability of U.S. power.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross for The New York Times
item.media:description: The United States Supreme Court granted an unprecedented expansion of executive power, worrying the country’s allies.

item.title: They Came for Spiritual Revival, Only to Be Trapped in a Deadly Panic
item.description: Family members streamed to hospitals in the Indian state of Uttar Pradesh to identify loved ones after at least 121 people — nearly all women — died in a stampede at a guru’s gathering.
item.dc:creator: Suhasini Raj
item.media:credit: Saumya Khandelwal for The New York Times
item.media:description: Families visited hospitals late into the night to see if their relatives were among the scores killed on Tuesday at a guru’s gathering in the northern Indian state of Uttar Pradesh.

item.title: An Uproar Over a Chinese Doping Case, Except in China
item.description: Chinese state news and social media has been virtually silent about 23 swimmers secretly testing positive in 2021, even as the issue is being debated widely abroad, including in Congress.
item.dc:creator: David Pierson
item.media:description: Chinese swimmers celebrating their gold medal in the women’s 4x200-meter freestyle relay at the Tokyo Olympics in July 2021.

item.title: China Seizes Taiwanese Fishing Boat As Tensions Rise
item.description: The authorities in Taipei have demanded that Beijing release the boat and its five crew members, who are being held in custody.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley and Amy Chang Chien
item.media:description: Hsieh Ching-chin, a spokesman for Taiwan’s Coast Guard Administration, said the crew members should not become pawns in the tensions between China and Taiwan.

item.title: U.N. Panel Adds to Chorus Calling for Russia’s Release of Evan Gershkovich
item.description: The U.N. Working Group on Arbitrary Detentions said the Wall Street Journal reporter was being punished for covering the war in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: Evan Gershkovich, a reporter for The Wall Street Journal, during a hearing in Russia.

item.title: Jay Slater’s Disappearance on Tenerife Spurs Online Sleuths and Speculation
item.description: Jay Slater disappeared on the Spanish island of Tenerife last month. His whereabouts sparked intense online speculation.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai and Claire Moses
item.media:description: A missing person poster that has been distributed with a photograph of Mr. Slater, who disappeared in Tenerife.

item.title: You See a Hedge. He Sees Something Else.
item.description: Tim Bushe decided to shape the hedges in his London neighborhood into a menagerie. They’ve become a local attraction.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai and Andrew Testa
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: A “reclining nude” hedgerow, which Mr. Bushe said was inspired by the artist Henry Moore.

item.title: On the Kenya-Tanzania Border, an Elephant Hunting Ban Has Collapsed
item.description: Five bulls from the area around a Kenyan wildlife reserve have been shot and killed in Tanzania in recent months. The countries have very different conservation strategies.
item.dc:creator: Shola Lawal
item.media:description: A bull elephant just outside Amboseli National Park in southern Kenya.

item.title: How China and Russia Compete, and Cooperate, in Central Asia
item.description: China’s leader, Xi Jinping, and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia are courting regional leaders and pushing an alternative to the U.S.-led order.
item.dc:creator: Keith Bradsher and Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.media:credit: Kazakhstan's Presidential Press Office, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Kassym-Jomart Tokayev, president of Kazakhstan, welcomed Xi Jinping, China’s leader, at the international airport in Astana, Kazakhstan, on Tuesday.

item.title: Wednesday Briefing
item.description: Concerns about President Biden.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang for The New York Times
item.media:description: In the weeks before the debate, President Biden kept up a grueling travel schedule.

item.title: Iran’s Runoff Election: What to Know
item.description: Two candidates from opposite camps will compete for the presidency after no one garnered the number of votes needed last week to win.
item.dc:creator: Eve Sampson
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: A billboard in Tehran featuring pictures of the reformist candidate Dr. Masoud Pezeshkian, left, and the ultraconservative Saeed Jalili.

item.title: New Haitian Leader Visits Washington Seeking Additional Support
item.description: Haiti’s newly selected prime minister, Garry Conille, met with Democrats on Capitol Hill as well as Biden administration officials, seeking more help to combat the unrest in his country.
item.dc:creator: Robert Jimison
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross for The New York Times
item.media:description: Prime Minister Garry Conille of Haiti and members of his cabinet meeting with members of Congress at the Capitol on Tuesday.

item.title: Meloni Condemns Fascist Nostalgia Amid Scandal in Her Party’s Youth Wing
item.description: A news report used a hidden camera to show members of the youth arm of Brothers of Italy glorifying fascism.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.media:description: The news report was a blow to Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni, who has sought to cast herself as a modern, pragmatic leader of Italy, saying again and again that fascism belonged to history.

item.title: Wednesday Briefing: President Biden’s Lapses Increase
item.description: Plus, Israel’s generals want a truce.
item.dc:creator: Daniel E. Slotnik
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang for The New York Times
item.media:description: In the weeks before the debate, President Biden kept up a grueling travel schedule.

item.title: With Fists and Knives, Mobs Attack Syrian Refugees in Turkey
item.description: As economic woes grow in Turkey, groups of men have targeted Syrian refugees there. In response, fighters across the border in northern Syria have confronted Turkish soldiers.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard and Safak Timur
item.media:description: In Afrin, Syria, mourners carried the coffin of a man killed during protests against Turkey.

item.title: What Changes Would a Far-Right Government Bring to France?
item.description: The far-right party National Rally may end up governing France. Although it has evolved, its basic philosophy remains: Immigrants are a threat to the country’s safety and economy.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Porter
item.media:description: Jordan Bardella, the president of the right-wing party National Rally party, delivering a speech after preliminary results of the first round of the French parliamentary elections, in Paris, on Sunday.

item.title: Top US Official Holding Talks on Defusing Israel-Hezbollah Conflict
item.description: Amos Hochstein’s trip to France comes after comments by Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken that Israel had “effectively lost sovereignty” near the border with Lebanon because of attacks by Hezbollah.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.media:description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken at the State Department last week. On Monday he spoke of the dangers of the cross-border tensions between Israel and Lebanon-based Hezbollah militants.

item.title: Swedish Grandparents Can Be Paid to Babysit Under New Law
item.description: The Nordic country’s generous social services system now allows parents to transfer a portion of paid leave days to other non-parent caregivers.
item.dc:creator: Eve Sampson
item.media:credit: Rob Schoenbaum for The New York Times
item.media:description: Stockholm, the Swedish capital.

item.title: Lucy Letby Found Guilty of Attempted Murder of Another Baby
item.description: Ms. Letby, who had previously been found guilty in a string of murders and attempted murders, was retried and found guilty of another attempted murder.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:description: Journalists last year near Manchester Crown Court in northern England, where the nurse Lucy Letby received a life term for her previous convictions.

item.title: Stampede at Religious Event in India Kills More Than 100
item.description: The crush happened in hot and crowded conditions in Uttar Pradesh State, in northern India, and a medical official said the death toll could rise.
item.dc:creator: Suhasini Raj, Sameer Yasir and Hari Kumar
item.media:credit: Saumya Khandelwal for The New York Times

item.title: AfD Politician Björn Höcke Fined Again for Using Nazi Slogan
item.description: In his ruling against Björn Höcke, the judge said it was “essential that we counter the danger of old Nazi-era symbols from becoming acceptable again.”
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:description: Björn Höcke, center, was fined in May by the same court for using the same phrase.

item.title: North Korea’s New Must-Have Accessory: The Kim Jong-un Pin
item.description: With the introduction of the pin, Mr. Kim is said to be elevating his personality cult to the level once reserved for his father and grandfather.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:credit: Korean Central News Agency, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A photograph provided by North Korean state media was said to show a senior official wearing a pin with the image of Kim Jong-un during a ruling Workers’ Party meeting in Pyongyang on Sunday.

item.title: Israeli Generals, Low on Munitions, Want a Truce in Gaza
item.description: Israel’s military leadership wants a cease-fire with Hamas in case a bigger war breaks out in Lebanon, security officials say. It has also concluded that a truce would be the swiftest way to free hostages.
item.dc:creator: Ronen Bergman, Patrick Kingsley and Natan Odenheimer
item.media:description: A convoy of Israeli tanks near the border with Gaza on Monday.

item.title: In Ukraine War, A.I. Begins Ushering In an Age of Killer Robots
item.description: Driven by the war with Russia, many Ukrainian companies are working on a major leap forward in the weaponization of consumer technology.
item.dc:creator: Paul Mozur and Adam Satariano
item.media:credit: Sasha Maslov for The New York Times
item.media:description: Yurii Klontsak, a Ukrainian reservist, demonstrating how to use Wolly, an automated machine gun.

item.title: Netherlands Gets a New Government: What You Need to Know
item.description: The country has sworn in its first far-right government and is trying a new approach after nearly 14 years of Mark Rutte’s leadership. That could have broad implications for the nation and its standing in Europe.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.category: People's Party for Freedom and Democracy (Netherlands)
item.media:description: Dick Schoof, a former intelligence chief with no party affiliation, is the Netherlands’ new prime minister.

item.title: Prime Minister Viktor Orban of Hungary Visits Ukraine
item.description: Prime Minister Viktor Orban of Hungary, who has resisted European military and financial aid for Ukraine, met with President Volodymyr Zelensky in Kyiv.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins and Marc Santora
item.media:description: Prime Minister Viktor Orban of Hungary, left, and President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine last month at a European Union leaders’ summit in Brussels. Mr. Orban has long taken a Kremlin-friendly position on European support for Ukraine.

item.title: North Korea’s Latest Missile Test Suggests Arms Race With South
item.description: The North said it tested a missile with a “super-large warhead” on Monday. The South has similar missiles, meant to target underground bunkers.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:description: South Korean media covered North Korea’s latest missile test on Tuesday, using file video from an earlier launch.

item.title: Keir Starmer Is on the Cusp of Power in the U.K.
item.description: The Labour leader still struggles with the “performative side” of British politics, even as he has pulled his party to the center.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle and Mark Landler
item.media:description: Keir Starmer, the leader of Britain’s Labour Party, finds himself on the cusp of a potential landslide victory without the star power that marked previous British leaders on the doorstep of power.

item.title: Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Pete Marovich for The New York Times
item.media:description: Donald Trump on Jan. 6, 2021.

item.title: Air Europa Flight Hits Severe Turbulence, Fracturing Necks and Skulls
item.description: Four passengers were in intensive care after the flight from Spain to Uruguay hit turbulence that injured dozens. The plane made an emergency landing in Brazil.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas and Lis Moriconi
item.media:credit: Claudio Fernandez Arbes/Agence France-Presse, via Ugc/Afp Via Getty Images

item.title: Israel Frees Gaza Hospital Chief Held Without Charges for 7 Months
item.description: Rights groups denounced the detention of Al-Shifa Hospital’s director and thousands of other Gazans without trial, while Israeli leaders faulted his release as a government failure.
item.dc:creator: Hiba Yazbek, Johnatan Reiss and Thomas Fuller
item.media:description: Mohammad Abu Salmiya, the director of Al-Shifa Hospital, in Khan Younis, in southern Gaza, on Monday. He was released after more than seven months in Israeli detention.

item.title: Alert Level Raised at U.S. Bases in Europe Over Russian Threats
item.description: Officials said there was no specific intelligence about possible Russian attacks on American bases, but Moscow has made vague threats over Ukraine’s use of long-range weapons on its territory.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes and John Ismay
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: U.S. military bases in Europe are at condition “charlie,” the highest level of readiness that can be reasonably sustained over a long period of time.

item.title: In Nigeria, Female Suicide Bombers Are a Terrorist Group’s Hidden Weapon
item.description: Suicide bombers killed at least 32 people in three attacks in a Nigerian city once controlled by Boko Haram. Women, said experts, are more likely to go unnoticed when carrying out terrorist attacks.
item.dc:creator: Eve Sampson
item.media:description: Injured victims of a suicide bomb attack receiving treatment at a hospital in Maiduguri, Nigeria, on Sunday.

item.title: Hurricane Beryl Moves Toward Jamaica After Ravaging Eastern Caribbean
item.description: The storm, now a Category 4 hurricane, left extreme damage in its wake as it headed toward Jamaica.
item.dc:creator: Emiliano Rodríguez Mega
item.media:description: The Bridgetown Fisheries in Barbados on Monday. Storm surge there caused significant damage to fishing vessels, sinking at least 20 boats.

item.title: Tuesday Briefing: Top Court Gives Trump Significant Immunity
item.description: Plus, what’s next for France.
item.dc:creator: Daniel E. Slotnik
item.media:credit: Pete Marovich for The New York Times
item.media:description: Donald Trump on Jan. 6, 2021.

item.title: France’s Snap Election: Here Is What’s at Stake
item.description: France’s July 7 election could see the country’s nationalist, anti-immigrant party achieve a majority, or send the nation into months of political deadlock.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.media:description: The fate of President Emmanuel Macron’s second term is at stake in a snap election that is now underway in France.

item.title: Release of Al-Shifa Hospital’s Director Sets Off Uproar Across Israel
item.description: The Israelis had sought to link the hospital director to Hamas operations at Al-Shifa, and his release after seven months without charges prompted extensive finger-pointing.
item.dc:creator: Hiba Yazbek and Ephrat Livni
item.media:description: Mohammad Abu Salmiya, the director of Al-Shifa Hospital, in Khan Younis, in southern Gaza, on Monday. He was released after more than seven months in Israeli detention.

item.title: The Center Collapses in France, Leaving Macron Marooned
item.description: Squeezed by the far-right National Rally party and the left, President Emmanuel Macron faces a country that may prove ungovernable.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron of France at a polling station in Le Touquet, northern France, on Sunday.

item.title: Ismail Kadare’s Best Books: A Guide
item.description: Kadare received the inaugural International Booker Prize in 2005. In his books, the prolific Albanian author offered a window into the psychology of oppression. Here’s where to start.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: The General of the Dead Army (Book)
item.media:description: Ismail Kadare died on July 1, at 88, in the Albanian capital, Tirana.

item.title: Trump Organization Signs Contract for New Saudi Tower
item.description: The residential high-rise tower in Jeddah is the latest of several developments that the former president’s company has planned for the Middle East.
item.dc:creator: Eric Lipton
item.category: Dar Al Arkan Real Estate Development Co
item.media:credit: Jenna Schoenefeld for The New York Times
item.media:description: Before Donald J. Trump was elected president in 2016, his organization had planned to build a tower in the Middle East, but the deal was shelved.

item.title: Nine Killed in Central Seoul After Car Plows Into Pedestrians
item.description: The deadly crash occurred near a busy intersection in front of city hall in central Seoul.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:description: Police and rescuers near a car involved in a crash that killed nine people on Monday night in Seoul.

item.title: For South Africa’s Cabinet, Bigger May Not Mean Better
item.description: To accommodate a broad and diverse alliance of parties, President Cyril Ramaphosa increased the size of his executive team. Now the challenge is getting a diverse group of politicians to agree.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon
item.media:description: President Cyril Ramaphosa of South Africa, shown being sworn in as a parliamentarian last month, announced a broad new coalition cabinet on Sunday.

item.title: Ukraine Says It Foiled Russian Plot Echoing String of Coup Bids
item.description: While the viability of the plan was not immediately clear, officials said it was a reminder that the Kremlin remained determined to bring down President Volodymyr Zelensky.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Maidan Square in Kyiv, Ukraine. Security officials described a plan that would have begun with a protest before shifting to an attempt to seize the Parliament building.

item.title: Release of Gazan Hospital Director Draws Outcry in Israel
item.description: Mohammad Abu Salmiya, the director of Al-Shifa Hospital in Gaza City, was released on Monday after more than seven months in Israeli detention without charges.
item.dc:creator: Hiba Yazbek
item.media:description: Mohammad Abu Salmiya, the director of Al-Shifa Hospital, behind the lectern, speaks to reporters in southern Gaza after his release from Israeli custody on Monday.

item.title: France Reacts to Big Far-Right Wins in First Round of Snap Election
item.description: Many expressed shock that Marine Le Pen’s nationalist party was so close to power after the first round of a snap election.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Porter
item.media:description: Demonstrators at a rally after the announcement of the results of the first round of French parliamentary elections at the Place de la République in Paris on Sunday.

item.title: A Culture War Erupted Over U.K. Stately Homes. Who Won?
item.description: A battle over the history of Britain’s prized country houses offers a window into the national mood before a pivotal election.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times

item.title: The Rubik Cube Turns 50
item.description: Mathematicians and hobbyists have had a half-century of fun exploring the 43 billion billion permutations of Erno Rubik’s creation.
item.dc:creator: Siobhan Roberts
item.media:credit: Akos Stiller for The New York Times
item.media:description: “My method was understanding,” Erno Rubik said of the iconic twisty puzzle that he invented in 1974.

item.title: Palestinian Fighters in West Bank Seek to Emulate Hamas in Gaza
item.description: In the towns of Tulkarm and Jenin, armed militants are flocking to more hard-line factions, such as Hamas and Islamic Jihad, while the Israeli military tries to rein them in.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger and Sergey Ponomarev
item.media:description: Palestinian militants last month in Tulkarm, in the West Bank. Refugee camps in the West Bank have been hotbeds of militancy for years, well before the war in Gaza.

item.title: Chinese Rocket Crashes After Accidentally Launching During Test
item.description: The commercial company Space Pioneer said the accident occurred because of a structural failure in the connection between the rocket and its testing platform.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang and John Liu
